node.text:
Brazil's president once again attempts to erase the indigenous way of life through his policies and actions. At the beginning of February, Bolsonaro introduced Proposed Law (PL) 191, which would open up demarcated territories for mining. As if his message weren't clear enough, he is also attempting to appoint an ex-missionary to lead a crucial federal department responsible for the protection of indigenous peoples.

All of these decisions are not surprising when phrases such as "the Amazon is for the Brazilians" or "too much land for a handful of 'indians' [sic]" are common in President Jair Bolsonaro's speeches. In fact, being openly against indigenous rights is one of the president's main talking points, a position that he sees as both "nationalistic" and "logical." There is nothing logical about Bolsonaro's forceful attempt to take land away from indigenous people who have originally lived in and protected the Amazon Forest for thousands of years. These racist and calculated attacks are being conducted on many fronts, with Bolsonaro at the helm.

Indigenous peoples have the right to be, to see their right to self-determination fully observed. Any system or policy or government appointment that attempts to deny this right must be seen as an open attack against all humankind. Protecting indigenous lives is the only way to protect the Amazon, for the benefit of humanity as a whole. 
Video: @midiaindiaoficial 
#Indigenousrights #protecttheamazon #indigenousleaders #rainforests #amazon #isolatedpeoples

VICTORY OF THE INDIGENOUS MOVEMENT!

The President of the Chamber of Deputies Rodrigo Maia compromised to not move forward the bill 191 which provides for the opening of Indigenous lands for mining, hydroelectric, agribusiness and exploration of oil and natural gas.

Last week Maia had started on the project that was sent by the Presidency and created a special commission so the bill would transact in the house, however he assured today in front of Indigenous Leaderships and Deputies of the Mixed Parliamentary Front for the defence of Indigenous People's rights that bill will not be proceed.

In the occasion it was also given to the President of the Chamber the Piaraçu manifest written by Leaderships during the Meeting of Mebengokrê People which was idealized by the Kayapó Leader Raoni Metukire.

Photo: @midiaindiaoficial/ @ericmarky 
#Devastationbill #IndigenousRights #NoMining #ProtectTheAmazon #Amazon #rainforest

“We can’t feed our children oil. We want the Amazon to be valued for what it is, not just an economic resource. We are standing up for our lives, yours, the entire world and for the lives of our future generations.” - Patricia Gualinga, 2013

And unfortunately, her speech still rings true today. Oil and other extractive industries across the Amazon threaten the way of life for indigenous people. The loss of people, the loss of language, the loss of culture, will reverberate throughout the history of this Earth and its heartbreaking. 
But the fate of the Amazon, can be luscious and green if left in the hands of indigenous peoples. We can fiercely advocate for the original stewards of the rainforest, we still have time to do the right thing. Will you join us in our call protect the Amazon and the rights of its people? Share, repost & tag us. ✊🏽 [Description of picture] A woman is taking a break in an assembly meeting in Sarayaku and pouring some chicha, a traditional fermented yucca drink. 
PC: @kevinmichaelkoenig .

We deeply regret the death of Israel Viteri & express our condolences to the Viteri Gualinga family and the Kichwa People of #Sarayaku. Let us remember Israel for his way with people, his joy and his service as the first pilot of the Kichwa Nationality.

Students at over 50 campuses are taking action today for #fossilfueldivestmentday. We must fully divest from fossil fuels to protect and preserve the #AmazonRainforest. They are demanding their universities divest from fossil fuels & reinvest in regenerative, community-controlled economies. Join + & support their movement. #Repost• @guajajarasonia 
Sonia Guajarara, executive coordinator of the Association of Indigenous Peoples of Brazil (APIB), participated in the protest and march for the climate "Fire Drill Friday", alongside allies and representatives of indigenous youth and of Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women movement. The urgency of the climate change talks is necessary to fight for the environment and the climate. @janefonda decided to dedicate her life to fighting for climate change and brought with her other artists. The march was a success, the streets of the cities were taken by the crowd. 
Financing an endless war is an existential threat to human life and one of the main causes of climate change. The liberation of mining on indigenous lands is another way of financing this war, and that is what the President of Brazil, Jair Bolsonaro, is trying to do now. That is why there is an urgent need to come together and strengthen ourselves in defence of the planet!

Organized by @greenpeaceusa in Los Angeles, in partnership with @codepinkalert, which has been promoting these protests in Washington DC, "Fire Drill Friday" will take place one Friday a month in different cities, to draw attention to the urgency of intersectoral analysis around climate change.

Sonia Guajaraja is in the United States for an agenda that includes lectures at universities, meetings with partners and allies, and for support to the Brazilian documentary competing for the Oscar, The Edge of Democracy by @petracostal. Saturday, February 8, the day before the Oscars, @xryouth.la were striking at the Hollywood sign, and Sonia participated as a guest of the Artists for the Amazon. "There is no Hollywood on a dead planet". Photos: @gasparinikaingang

#firedrillfriday #protecttheamazon #indigenousrights #amazon #losangeles #hollywoodsbleeding

We partnered with Oscar nominee Joaquin Phoenix, and Extinction Rebellion for a short film urging action on the climate and ecological emergency! Phoenix is joined in the film, entitled Guardians of Life, by an array of Hollywood stars including Rosario Dawson, Matthew Modine, Q'orianka Kilcher, Oona Chaplin, Adria Arjona, and Albert Hammond Jr. of The Strokes.

Right now, indigenous peoples and their lands are increasingly under threat from vast economic exploitation across the Amazon — a rainforest vital for the health of our planet. The Amazon removes about 5% of total emissions caused by human activity. Without the Amazon, the planet would be warming faster than scientists already observe. 
But, the Amazon rainforest is at RISK. Just last year, over 11.2 M hectares in the Brazilian and Bolivian Amazon burned. New analysis of extensive satellite imagery revealed that many of the fires were actually burning the remains of areas that were recently deforested. 
In Brazil, the threats are escalating: Bolsonaro’s Administration recently announced plans to hand out indigenous lands to the very industries responsible for deforestation. In the Brazilian Amazon, those industries are land speculation, mining, and agribusiness, specifically soy and cattle. Companies in these industries are bankrolled by global financial institutions like BlackRock, JP Morgan Chase, HBSC, BNP Paribas and Vanguard. They too, are responsible for the Amazon's destruction. 
But it doesn’t have to be this way. According to scientific studies, indigenous lands are “currently the most important barrier to Amazon deforestation.” Indigenous peoples are the best protectors of the Amazon rainforest, so protecting indigenous rights is instrumental. .
.
.
.
.
@extinctionrebellion
#ActNow #GuardiansOfLife #ClimateChange #ProtectTheAmazon #AmazonRainforest #Amazonia #Amazon

We're looking at untold destruction — not just of the Amazon but of our entire planet. We must ensure the protection of indigneous peoples who are on the front lines defending the #Amazon rainforest. We can still stave off the worst of climate change. .
.

Yesterday, Bolsonaro proposed a bill to permit mining on indigenous land. Indigenous peoples are denouncing the government's proposal while demanding that their voices be heard. They reject any act that legalizes mining on indigenous lands and demand their right to free, prior, and informed consultation, as guaranteed by the International Labor Organization’s Convention 169. @guajajarasonia .
.
.

#indigenous #indigenousrights #indigenousland #Brazil

NAPO in EMERGENCY!

The government of Ecuador without prior and informed consultation has awarded more than 7,000 hectares to the company Terraearth Resources SA, in the province of Napo, in the Ecuadorian Amazon, directly affecting the parishes and communities of Tena, Pro. Napo, Talag, Pano and CJ Arosemena Tola, and threatening the entire Amazon ecosystem. 
NO to mining projects that threaten life and nature! KAWSAYMANDA WANKURISHUN .
.
.
.

#NapoResiste #TenaResiste #AmazoniaResiste

Re-Posted @guajajarasonia 
The * Coordination of Indigenous Organizations in the Brazilian Amazon * - COIAB, makes public, in a short and direct way, to denounce the crimes of genocide and ethnocide that will be committed against our isolated relatives and of recent contact if concretize the appointment of a person linked to the activities of religious proselytism for the Funai sector that works with our relatives. Our families have historically suffered due to missionaries - many of them from the New Tribes of Brazil Mission (MNTB) - who made forced contact with our grandparents and grandparents. Forced contact was made through lies, violence and death threats. Through forced contact they tried to evangelize us, they offered us gifts to attract and deceive us, often these gifts were contaminated with diseases, which led many of our relatives to die. Also through lies and threats, on many occasions, these groups of missionaries removed our relatives from our ancestral territories to other strange regions, brought together several of our different peoples, their survivors, in the same place, forcing us from that moment to abandon our socio-cultural systems and our beliefs. 
They insistently tried - through lies, threats, physical punishment, among others - to co-opt us to submit to their ideas and their way of thinking the world. Proselytizing missionary activity caused us physical death, socio-cultural death, destruction of our physical and spiritual territories. We know that today there are proselytists and evangelical religious groups allied with criminal ruralist groups that plan to seize what remains of our territories. We are sure that the activity of proselytizing missionaries goes hand in hand with the destruction of our last territories. In our view, the appointment of this missionary to work with our isolated relatives means yet another attack by this racist and prejudiced government against our peoples, our families. We have the right to think and live differently from non-indigenous society. We have the right to our territories! #indigenousrights #protecttheamazon

We do not inherit the EARTH from our ancestors, we borrow it from our children. - Native American Proverb .

Black Agouti, with its coarse and glossy fur, can jump up to 2 meters high! Found in the northwestern Amazon in South America, they inhabit regions of southern Venezuela, eastern Colombia, eastern Ecuador, western Brazil and northeastern Peru. They live in close proximity to water, usually near streams and are frugivores. Habitat destruction, is an active population threat. .
.

Support youth climate activists like @helenagualinga “Along with youth  and Indigenous people from all around the world  I attended COP 25 in Madrid. With the hope of seeing strong and efficient climate policies being made. Instead  we saw them promoting false solutions, favoring the fossil fuel industry. The very same industry that is causing climate change! 
It’s time we restore the power to the people.
We demand the end of fossil fuel extraction. We demand our leaders to take action.

Now Youth  from all around the world have come together to kick @POLLUTERSOUT of lands, governments and Climate Negotiations! 
Swipe for important message! 
Join @pollutersout now. 
Share!” #FossilFuelIndustryOutofCOP26
#protecttheamazon #amazon #cop25

There are already over 500 indigenous leaders from all over Brazil participating in the Mebemgokrê meeting, which according to the people of Xingú, is the largest meeting in the region since the constituent period.

Today the leader Sonia Guajajara has joined other leaders discussing issues such as leasing Indigenous Lands, Ferrogrão and other mega-enterprises affecting their territories, outsourcing and municipalizing indigenous health, the tragic dismantling of indigenous policies, the growing dangers facing peoples living in voluntary isolation, the prohibition of public services to indigenous living in non-homologated lands, among others.

Those present discussed resistance and mobilization among peoples strategies, the meetings and their struggle agenda, the role of youth and women and the organization of the indigenous movement in the country.
.
.
.
.
.
#Xingu #Brazil #indigenous #protecttheearth #protecttheplanet #protect #amazon #protecttheamazon 
Photos: @midianinja and @midiaindiaoficial

Deforestation is the second largest driver of #ClimateChange and BlackRock is the world’s biggest investor in deforestation. Yesterday, after more than a year of increasing pressure from climate activists, investors, legislators, and thought leaders, BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, in his highly-anticipated annual letter to CEOs and clients, announced a sweeping new set of policies which aim to put climate change and sustainability at the center of Blackrock’s business model. This announcement begins that reshaping, BUT it is not enough.

BlackRock has not made clear whether deforestation risk or indigenous rights will be a part of BlackRock’s new engagement and voting priorities. For the good, the blah and the gaps click the link in our bio! .
.
.
.
.
📸: @naheca12 & @ada.bot

The Hoatzin (Opisthocomus hoazin) is arguably the weirdest and most prehistoric looking bird in the world.↟ Photographed in the heart of the Ecuadorian Amazon, this unique bird strictly feeds on leaves, and lives in the trees. The Amazon is one of the most breathtaking Ecosystems I was fortunate enough to lay my eyes on this year.  It desperately needs our support. 🌿✨💗 •_•_•_•_•_•_•_•_•_•_•_•

Indigenous people are stewards for 1/4 of the world’s land surface. They protect 80% of global biodiversity. They are by far, the best protectors of the Amazon rainforest. Indigenous peoples depend on rainforests’ health for food, medicine, water and LIFE. We must stand with indigenous people to protect our rainforests and the climate. The fate of the Amazon is the fate of the world.

Video: Sandra Tukup of the Chuah peoples in the Ecuadorian Amazon at #COP25 in Madrid, Spain. .
